prior_works.title: AI2: Safety and Robustness Certification of Neural Networks with Abstract Interpretation
prior_works.authors: R. Gehr, M. Mirman, D. Drachsler-Cohen, P. Tsankov, S. Chaudhuri, M. Vechev
prior_works.role: Foundational framework introducing abstract interpretation for neural network certification
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s notion of an abstract image and provable, sound over-approximations directly builds on AI2’s idea of propagating abstract domains through computation graphs to certify downstream behavior.

prior_works.title: An Abstract Domain for Certifying Neural Networks (DeepPoly)
prior_works.authors: G. Singh, T. Gehr, M. Püschel, M. Vechev
prior_works.role: Abstract-domain design for tight piecewise-linear bounds
prior_works.relationship_sentence: DeepPoly’s tight linear relaxations of nonlinear operations informed the design of efficient piecewise-linear abstractions that the authors extend to rendering-specific operators not covered by standard tools.

prior_works.title: Efficient Neural Network Robustness Certification with General Activation Functions (CROWN)
prior_works.authors: H. Zhang, T.-W. Weng, P.-Y. Chen, C.-J. Hsieh
prior_works.role: Linear relaxation–based perturbation analysis (LiRPA) for end-to-end bound propagation
prior_works.relationship_sentence: CROWN’s LiRPA principles underpin the paper’s end-to-end propagation of bounds from 3D pose/scene uncertainties through rendering into neural networks, motivating the extension with custom bounds for nonstandard operators.

prior_works.title: NeRF: Representing Scenes as Neural Radiance Fields for View Synthesis
prior_works.authors: B. Mildenhall, P. P. Srinivasan, M. Tancik, J. T. Barron, R. Ramamoorthi, R. Ng
prior_works.role: Rendering model with cumulative transmittance products along rays
prior_works.relationship_sentence: NeRF’s volume rendering equation, which accumulates colors via cumulative products and sums, directly motivates the paper’s custom abstraction for cumulative product summations to certify images under 3D semantic perturbations.

prior_works.title: Neural 3D Mesh Renderer
prior_works.authors: H. Kato, Y. Ushiku, T. Harada
prior_works.role: Differentiable rasterization pipeline with depth-based aggregation
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The z-buffer–style, sorting-based aggregation and per-pixel barycentric interpolation in differentiable rasterization informed the need for and design of sound, piecewise-linear bounds for sorting/aggregation within the rendering pipeline.

prior_works.title: Computability of global solutions to factorable nonconvex programs via convex underestimating problems (McCormick relaxations)
prior_works.role: Convex/concave envelopes for bilinear and product terms
prior_works.relationship_sentence: McCormick’s bilinear envelopes provide the mathematical basis for bounding multiplicative interactions, which the paper leverages to construct linear bounds for cumulative product operations in volume rendering.

prior_works.title: Matrix Perturbation Theory
prior_works.role: Perturbation bounds for inverses and stability of linear algebra operations
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Classical perturbation results for matrix inversion guide the paper’s abstraction of camera pose inversion under uncertainty, ensuring sound bounds that reflect conditioning of the projection/extrinsics.

synthesis_narrative:
Abstract Rendering unifies certified perception with physically grounded 3D-to-2D image formation by propagating uncertainty through the rendering pipeline into neural networks. This synthesis rests on abstract interpretation and linear-relaxation bound propagation pioneered by AI2 and CROWN/DeepPoly: these works establish how to represent sets of inputs with tractable abstract domains and push tight, piecewise-linear bounds through complex computation graphs for certification. The paper extends this paradigm beyond pixel-level perturbations to 3D semantic uncertainty by introducing abstractions for rendering-specific operators that standard LiRPA tools do not support.

Two strands from computer graphics and vision shape the operator choices. NeRF’s volume rendering formalism introduces cumulative transmittance products along rays; bounding these motivates tailored linear envelopes for cumulative product summations, mathematically grounded in McCormick’s convex–concave relaxations for products. Differentiable rasterization, exemplified by the Neural 3D Mesh Renderer, highlights depth-based, sorting-driven aggregation and barycentric interpolation; this spurs the development of sound bounds for sorting/select-and-aggregate behavior within rendering. Finally, camera pose uncertainty requires inverting perturbed transforms; Matrix Perturbation Theory provides the stability analysis and inverse sensitivity needed to design safe abstractions for matrix inversion.

By marrying abstract-interpretation-style certification with the core primitives of modern rendering, the paper constructs an abstract image—constraints that provably overapproximate all images generated by continuous pose/scene variations—and then composes this with downstream networks. The result is a principled, certifiable pipeline for semantic (3D) perturbations, concretely enabled by the prior foundations in neural verification, differentiable rendering, and convex relaxations.
